info.text:
This tool implements a predictive model of Pedestrian Volume estimated using an Ordinary Least Squares (simple linear) regression method. The volumes estimated cover a 12-hour period (morning to evening).

The model is based on a combination of environmental and demographic factors that showed a relationship with observed levels of pedestrian activity. The model may be applied to road and trail segments. For “average” facilities, this tool will generate plausible estimates, but it does not deal well with outliers, and some facilities may show “negative” values. This model is most useful for evaluating the relative level of activity that would be expected under different conditions.

We have included the Ordinary Least Squares pedestrian model in the Non-Motorized Toolkit primarily for completeness (all models in the UMN report linked in the tool documentation have been implemented). You should use the Negative Binomial version of the model (which forces values not to be negative) if you would prefer to see results that only contain positive numbers, and that thus might be directly compared to your own counts.

The coefficients for the model were estimated by a team from the University of Minnesota (UMN) based on counts collected in Minneapolis, and published by the UMN Center for Transportation Studies in July 2012. The model implementation presented here was developed by the Open Technology Group (Morrisville, NC) under contract with the Federal Highway Administration.

The full report on the study and model development is available in the tool documentation links.
info.name: Pedestrian Volume (OLS Method, UMN)

links.title: Understanding the Use of Non-Motorized Transportation Facilities (Report)

output.description: You may override the default field name in which results from this tool are reported by entering a different name here.  The name you enter may be adjusted so it is not the same as any fields already in your input data.

elements.description: Field name that will contain 12-hour pedestrian volume
elements.label: Result Field
elements.name: result

output.name: results
output.label: Result Variable

elements.name: Pctnonwhite
elements.description: Fraction of neighborhood residents that are non-white (range 001)

elements.name: PctU5_O65
elements.description: Fraction of neighborhood residents over 65 or under 5 (range 0-1)

elements.name: Pctw4ormore
elements.description: Fraction of neighborhood residents with a college education (range 0-1)

elements.name: MedHHInc
elements.description: Median household income (1000's of dollars)

elements.name: Crime
elements.description: Average number of violent crimes/year

elements.name: PDperkm2
elements.description: Population density (persons per square kilometer)

elements.name: LUMix
elements.description: Measure of mixing of land uses (range 0-1)

elements.name: WatDist_km
elements.description: Distance from nearest body of water (kilometers)

elements.name: CBDdist_km
elements.description: Distance from central business district (kilometers)

elements.name: EmployAccess
elements.description: Number of jobs within 30 minutes by transit, less than 3 transfers.

elements.name: Principal
elements.description: Principal arterial street (1/0)

elements.name: Arterial
elements.description: Arterial street (1/0)

elements.name: Collector
elements.description: Collector street  (1/0)

elements.name: BusRoute
elements.description: Presence of one of more bus routes (1/0)

elements.name: OffstreetTrail
elements.description: Off-street trail (1/0)

input.description: Specify the location of each required parameter field in the input file. You may ignore certain properties, and you may also choose to specify a global value to be applied to all features (Global values are listed in the next section).
input.label: Input File Fields
input.name: data

input.description: These model parameters are the same for each feature, and reflect background conditions that apply to the entire model scenario.  Certain parameters here can be specified either as fields for each input feature, or as global parameters.  You must set the corresponding Input File Field to "Global" in order to use the corresponding value from this section.

elements.name: globalCrime
elements.description: Average number of "nearby" violent crimes/year (WARNING: not used if you provide a field for Crime in the input file)

elements.name: globalTmax
elements.description: Recorded daily high temperature (Celsius)

elements.name: globalPrecip
elements.description: Recorded precipitation (cm)

elements.name: globalYear
elements.description: Level variable indicating year count occurred (offset from year 2007)

input.name: global
input.label: Global Parameters

input.description: These are the estimated coefficients for the Ordinary Least Squares Pedestrian hourly volume model. They are presented for reference only and should not be changed without a full model re-estimation.

elements.name: constant
elements.description: Constant value
